The EQUIP Project supports the commitment, under PEPFAR 3.0, to impact the global burden of HIV/AIDS by fast-tracking cost-effective treatment and prevention initiatives. EQUIP provides technical assistance to the Ministry of Health (MOH), PEPFAR Uganda, and other stakeholders through cost and impact modeling and economic evaluation.
During FY16, in collaboration with the MOH and other partners, Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.6: Adult Care and Support. All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. All health facility-based care for HIV-exposed children and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.18: Treatment/Pediatric Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. objectives

The EQUIP Project supports the commitment, under PEPFAR 3.0, to impact the global burden of HIV/AIDS by fast-tracking cost-effective treatment and prevention initiatives. EQUIP provides technical assistance to the Ministry of Health (MOH), PEPFAR Uganda, and other stakeholders through cost and impact modeling and economic evaluation.
During FY16, in collaboration with the MOH and other partners, EQUIP carried out a study that modeled 1) the impact of implementing the National Test and Start and the Differentiated Service Delivery Model (DSDM) Guidelines both on the total cost of the national treatment program and on HIV incidence and mortality; 2) the potential cost savings from implementing differentiated models of HIV care; and 3) the funding gap that Uganda potentially faces from implementing both sets of guidelines. The MOH used findings from this study as an input to the National Test and Startt and DSDM Guidelines.
Uganda is now set to implement a number of DSDM approaches including multiple month dispensing, adherence clubs, client-led ART delivery models, and community distribution points for specified groups of eligible ART patients. These target population groups include pediatric, PMTCT, and TB/HIV patients. EQUIP’s ingredients-based costing is based on assumptions about resource utilization under the various models and highlights potential treatment cost savings that could be realized if new models of care are scaled up. Further studies are required to determine the actual costs and additional benefit of these models beyond cost savings, such as improved adherence, reduced costs for patients, and the degree to which such models ease the burden on facilities.
